Author: Dave Carson
Title: So here were all are....

Content:
<img class=" size-full wp-image-37 aligncenter" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/hate-job.jpg" alt="hate job" width="640" height="426" />

We all have those friends who, on a night out, will whine and moan about their jobs. They don't like their manager, so and so is a bitch and they could manage the place better.

When I'm on the receiving end of one of these I roll out my personal mantra:
<blockquote>If you don't like what you do, then do something else,

If you like what you do but not where you do it, do it somewhere else</blockquote>
We spend a lot of time working and doing a job you don't like is just a waste of time for all concerned; you, your colleagues, your employer and the people around you.

Now that may all sound very flippant, but that's how I've gotten to where I am today.

When I left school I trained as a Motor Mechanic but after 7 years or so that wasn't doing it for me.

I then had an opportunity to enrol on a Mechanical Engineering degree and despite a number of people telling me I probably wasn't smart enough I grabbed the chance. I gradated and now have a BEng honors degree to my name.

Not finding a suitable job in MechEng I decided to fall back on a hobby of mine, computer programming, a skill now sharpened during my degree studies.

I secured my first Software Developer role soon afterwards, moving onto another when I outgrew the first. Then another.

Today I work as a Software Development contractor, picking the work I want to do, the work that interests and challenges me, and passing on the rest.

I find it hard to see what I do as 'work' sometimes - I enjoy it that much. Yes I have difficult days like everyone else; be it the code I'm working on, the people I'm working with or the client I'm working for. But I can see some many positives in what I do that these things are just blips - and I can live with those.

I've declined contract renewals because the projects weren't doing it for me, or because because the client was just too difficult to work for.

I've taken lower paid contracts for more interesting work and travelled further on a commute than I ever wanted to for projects and clients that are engaging and fulfilling.

<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=agbsQbMi7x0"><img class=" size-full wp-image-34 alignright" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/what_do_you_desire-youtube.png" alt="what_do_you_desire-youtube" width="251" height="144" /></a>

I recently came across a <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=agbsQbMi7x0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">motivational video onÂ </a><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=agbsQbMi7x0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">YouTube by Alan Watts which entitled 'What do you desire?'</a>. I encourage you to watch it - it could be the most enlightening 3 minutes you spend today.
Author: Dave Carson
Title: Don't complain to me about your job.....

Content:
<img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-41" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/brexit-signpost.jpg?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="169" />As a resident of the UK it would be laughable to think thatÂ I didn't have an opinion on BREXIT!

Before I start I should say that, like so many others in the UK (and around the world even), I have little interest in politics - or politicians for that matter. I feel that on the whole they are a bunch of self-interested, arrogant, power hungry muppets with their own welfare pushed well ahead of the rest of ours. Watching the House of Commons on the TV just makes me mad when I see these people laughing, jeering and waving their bits of paper around. It's like a school playground in there and I sometimes wonder what the politicians of old would make of their carrying on. Maybe that's the way it's always been.

Anyway, back to the matter in hand - BREXIT! The desire of just over half of the UK population who bothered their arse to vote decided that the UK should leave the EU and 'Take Back Control'. Those who didn't vote lost their voice and as far as I'm concerned should keep their opinions to themselves on all matters BREXIT - you had your chance and you dropped the ball!

For what it's worth, I voted to REMAIN in the EU - which puts me in the <a href="https://www.statista.com/statistics/567922/distribution-of-eu-referendum-votes-by-age-and-gender-uk/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">majority of men between 25 and 49</a> (I was when I voted!) voted to REMAIN. I'm glad I'm not in the age bracket that voted to LEAVE and plunged the UK into such turmoil. A lot of youngsters are pointing fingers at us, more mature citizens, blaming us for the shambles that we now face - I happy to say "Not Me!".

Why did I vote to remain?<img class="alignright size-thumbnail wp-image-42" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/i-voted-leave.jpg?w=147" alt="" width="147" height="150" />

Was it an rock solid belief that being in the EU was the absolute best thing for the UK and that we couldn't manage on our own? Hell No!

The reason is two fold
<ol>
 	<li>I had no faith in the government to be able to negotiate a deal of this magnitude with the EU - and and that's not to say that the other parties could have don't a better job in my opinion.</li>
 	<li>I really didn't believe what the politicians and the press were spinning. Sure, there were lies on both sides of the argument and the UK press have to shoulder the blame for good proportion of them. Whipping up fear with sensationalist headlines in order to sell their tatty rags and lead their more gullible readers. Even now, when the General Public can do nothing, we hear things like 'if we leave with no deal all flights will be grounded as we can't fly through EU airspace' while other reports claim this to be scaremongering.</li>
</ol>
Why doesn't everybody see what they are doing - it's like the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Emperor%27s_New_Clothes" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Emperor's New Clothes</a>. Are we really so blinded that we cannot make a decision for ourselves? Do we really need to follow others who are pushing their lies, all the time having their own, hidden agenda which has little to do with what we, the British people want. I'll tell you now, the newspaper owners really don't give a damn about immigration in the UK - but if it helps them make a political point so that they can line their own pockets (and that of their shareholders) then they'll tell you anything!

I voted REMAIN because I really didn't believe that the UK government (lower case 'g' is not accidental!) was capable of delivering the BREXIT being promised by the LEAVE campaign - and was proved right <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/eu-referendum-result-nigel-farage-nhs-pledge-disowns-350-million-pounds-a7099906.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">the very next day when Nigel Farage stated on Good Morning Britain that the claim that Â£350m a week would be ploughed into the NHS instead of being paid to the EU was undeliverable</a> and not a promise he made (despite it being all over the LEAVE campaign bus!). What the absolute ....... !

To cap it all Farage then announce 'his work here was done' and resigned from UKIP. Cameron quit as well. So many voices that were so vocal before were now silenced - probably thinking, 'Bloody Hell, we actually won! Now what??'. Quite happy to lead us into something but bailing as soon as the shit hits the fan.

The REMAIN campaign didn't cover themselves in glory either preferring to smear the other side instead of providing a proper argument for staying into the EU. Lies, gossip and scaremongering in the place of a constructive argument and, yes I'm going to say it, facts - actual concrete facts, that's what lost the vote.

Two years later and were are we? Frankly, in the shit and up to our bloody necks in it! We have a weak prime minister (again, lower case is not a mistake!) who has gone it alone and pussy footed around trying to appease the EU while at home her ministers keep resigning. We have a deal that the EU will grab with both hands and that the UK parliament (lower case for a reason .. I'm sure you get it by now) won't support. Well Done Mrs May - you have truly done well there!

We now face the real prospect of a No Deal situation - the worst possible outcome if you believe the politicians and the papers.

In amongst all this we have politicians on both sides of the house and the argument shovelling more shit and frankly making a bad situation even worse - and for why? For the betterment of the country? I sincerely doubt it.

At the time of writing Mrs May has fended off a leadership challenge from within her own party and, oddly, I think that was a good thing. Why? Because I like her....no, that's really not it. Think about it;

a) They should really be spending their time doing what they country voted for (as misguided as they may have been) and not stirring the pot for their own end,

b) Who would take over? Gove? Boris? Good grief, out of the frying pan or what!

c) If they did get in what could they do at this late stage in the process - probably nothing. Then all we would hear would be "well, it was already too late for me to save us from this mess" and they would carry on regardless, always bemoaning the fact that they could have done something if only they were in charge earlier.

Right now we are a laughing stock, not only in Europe but around the world. We've been show to be weak and compliant and we shall pay dearly for it - not that we already haven't, I mean how much has all this cost and who is picking up the bill? The UK Taxpayer that's who.

Of course we will never know what would have happened if the REMAIN campaign had won - only the 'winners' write history they say.

Author: Dave Carson
Title: The Elephant in the Room - BREXIT

Content:
<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/dec/26/treasury-urged-to-hire-woman-as-bank-of-england-governor" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img class="alignleft wp-image-52 size-medium" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2018/12/Screenshot_20181226-170254.png?w=150" alt="" width="150" height="300" /></a>

This came into my news feed over Christmas and I have to say that this sort of thing really irritates me.

MPs are <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/dec/26/treasury-urged-to-hire-woman-as-bank-of-england-governor" target="_blank" rel="noopener">calling for the Bank of England to 'try harder' to find a female replacement</a> for the current Governor, Mark Carney in order to help offset the gender imbalance.

What ever happened to the 'best person for the job getting the job'? If that happens to be a woman then great, hire her and give her the same support as if a man was in the post. But if it happens to be a man - why is that a problem?

You may say that it's easy for me to say that because I'm a man but let get something straight here;

I'm one of those people who cannot understand the gender pay gap. If two people are doing the same job with the same responsibilities then they should be paid the same amount for doing it. It becomes a bit of a grey area when salaries increase on a 'length of service' basis and in some industries like entertainment when your value may (rightly or wrongly) be judged by your popularity. But on the whole, same job, same responsibilities then same salary - simple.

By the same measure I also don't understand why companies need to be forced to hire women over men - sure they need to be reminded that they cannot discriminate between the two sexes but to favour one over the other on the basis of whether they are male or female is just wrong.

Think about it, if you got a job not because you were the best person for it but because the employer had to tick a box to say that 'we are reducing the gender imbalance within our company', how would that make you feel?

But it won't stop there will it. If it's going to be a woman in the role then that will ease the gender imbalance, but what about racial imbalance? So if she is now a non-white woman should she also be gay? What about disabled?

My answers to those questions are as above - if that person is the best person for the job is a non-white, gay woman in a wheelchair then give it to her and let her get on with it. But if it's not then surely that's OK too isn't it?

Before you head down to the comments and flame the hell out of my let me reiterate my position;
<blockquote>Companies need to be reminded that they cannot discriminate against candidates based on their sex, race, sexual orientation, disability etc. Not forced to hire someone in order to tick a box or achieve some arbitrary target set by government.</blockquote>
The best person for the job, that is the person who can do the job the most effectively and bring the most to it, should get the job - period.

To date it is has been an unfair system that has prevented women from achieving their full potential in the workplace and this is what has created the imbalance - but it seems to me that this isn't a drive for equality, it's a drive to reverse the balance.

Two wrongs don't make it right!
Author: Dave Carson
Title: The next Governor of the Bank of England should be a woman? Why exactly?

Content:
<img class="  wp-image-58 alignleft" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/01/grave_stone.jpg" alt="grave_stone" width="175" height="261" />No? Well then you can't be a UK resident or if you are then you can't have a television! Because we are being battered with adverts from the likes of Sun Life and Royal London, always around the time we're sitting down to relax after work, telling us how expensive funerals are and that it really isn't right to expect your family to have to think about this when you pass on.

While what they say may be true, do we really need it rammed down our throats day after day, week after week, month after month ... I think you get the idea.

Sometimes there are two or even three similar adverts in the same break, all reminding <img class="  wp-image-59 alignright" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/01/grim-reaper.jpg" alt="grim-reaper" width="142" height="106" />us that we are <strong>going to die</strong>. All preying on our fears and hoping that we will pick up the phone and sign up.

I don't know about you but I really don't need this sort of thing and it's no wonder there are so many people suffering depression in this country - and that's without Brexit.

Are these companies really that desperate for revenue that they need to constantly try to scare the money out of us with these doomful adverts.

Author: Dave Carson
Title: Have you thought about your funeral??

Content:
<img class="alignleft wp-image-65" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/01/gmail_logo.png?w=300" alt="" width="201" height="152" />My personal email account is a GMail account and, naturally enough, hosted by Google. I've had this account since around 2005 (13 years at the time of writing) and the mailbox is currently storing almost 5GB of messages.

So why would I want to move away from Google and lose my @gmail.com account - which all my friends, family have, not to mention sites like Amazon, Ebay and PayPal.

Well, as many users of the Google Inbox app on Android will know, it is being withdrawn in March 2019 and we are being 'encouraged' to move back to the 'new and improved' Gmail app we were pushed off a few years ago (because Inbox was the way-forward). I received a few nag messages when I opened Inbox so, knowing that there was little point in fighting Google on this, I thought I'd just do it and get it over with.

The fact is - I don't like it. Maybe it's because I have gotten into the Inbox way of doing things. I normally have '<a href="https://www.fastcompany.com/40507663/the-7-step-guide-to-achieving-inbox-zero-and-staying-there-in-2018" target="_blank" rel="noopener">inbox-zero</a>' which, let's face it, was the point of Inbox.

<img class="size-medium wp-image-64 alignright" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/01/gmail_app_ads-1.png?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="133" />I can get over that, I can archive the messages rather than tapping 'Done' but this isn't the thing that's pushed me to consider moving away altogether - I don't like the ads which mascarade as email messages.

Before you head down to the comments and start pointing out that Gmail is free and because of that I'm not a customer I'm the product - yes, I know all that and have accepted that for many, many years. But in todays climate I'm not sure I want to be anymore.

Yes, I get all sorts of "benefits" from GMail but I think I can make to without them - at least, I'm prepared to give it a go and see what happens.

So, I plan to create a new email account using the same provider that I use for my business email, <a href="https://www.fastmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Fastmail</a>. They've served me well and $50/year isn't going to break the bank.

<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-67" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/01/fastmail_logo-1.png?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="183" />Fastmail provide a <a href="https://www.fastmail.com/help/account/gmailimport.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">guide for migrating from GMail</a> and I plan to follow this to get the up and running. Then I'll turn off the Gmail account syncing on my phone (incoming mail to the Gmail account will be forwarded to the new account).

The only wrinkle I can see at the moment is that I already have the Fastmail app on my phone as it is connected to my business email account. I don't think that this app can support multiple email accounts (as the GMail app can).

Once I've got everything sorted the hard work will start - getting the word out about my new address. Friend and family should be easy enough but what about all those services that are linked to my GMail account?

Well, watch this space - I'll start with the main services I use, like Amazon, Ebay &amp; PayPal and post my experiences here.

When I'm done - hopefully you will be able to decide whether you want to make the leap or not.
Author: Dave Carson
Title: Time to move from GMail?

Content:
<img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-67" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/01/fastmail_logo-1.png?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="183" />Following on from my previous post I have now made some initial progress in my migration away from Gmail and while it's not the end-game, it is a milestone.

After checking that services like Amazon, PayPal the like will not meltdown if I change my password (which is also my username in these cases) I have now registered a new domain name for my email and also signed up for a new <a href="https://www.fastmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Fastmail</a> account - wiring the two together by entering the appropriate DNS settings.

While it wasn't strictly speaking necessary for me to have a domain all of my own I did want to retain control of my email. If I had just opted for the standard @fastmail.com domain then if I ever decided to migrate to another service I would have to notify all my contacts and subscribed services again.

This way my email address is mine and even if I decided to use another provider in the future the address would come with me and nobody else needed to know that I had moved.

<a href="https://www.fastmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Fastmail</a> have a great little utility that allowed me to import all my Gmail messages into the new account - placing them into a 'migrated' folder for future reference/searching. Because my Gmail account is protected by Two Factor Authentication I did need to create an App Password to allow the <a href="https://www.fastmail.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Fastmail</a> service to connect to my account.Â  This was easy enough and you can <a href="https://support.google.com/accounts/answer/185833?hl=en" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">read how to create an app password for Gmail here</a>. I can't say it was a quick process but then speed wasn't an issue here and I received an email into the new Inbox when it was completed confirming that almost 50k messages had been imported in around 5 hours.

I also exported my Contacts and Calendar from Google and imported this into my new account. I have to say it was quite enjoyable to run through the contact list and delete those who I really don't need anymore - it's amazing the cruft that builds up in there over time. I did need to clean up the contacts a little - some of the names hadn't come through correctly, e.g. "My Health Centre" just came in as "My Centre". Easily fixed and all good now.

Importing the Calendar was a little hairy - I managed to stuff it up the first time and ended up with contact birthdays going into the future but not as recurring events - so I could only delete them one at a time. I then noticed that my dental appointment (in a week or so) was not there and the realised that I had imported the wrong file.

There were two files in the export created by Google and I had imported the '<strong>#contacts@group.v.calendar.google.com.ics</strong>' file whereas I should have imported the '<strong>&lt;my-email&gt;@gmail.com.ics</strong>' instead. I'm sure the other file may be useful to others and could have been imported into another calendar (Fastmail allows multiple) but I really didn't need these events so I left them out. I ended up creating a new Calendar, deleting the original one and then importing the correct file. Happy days so far :-)
<h3>So where am I now?</h3>
I have a fully functional email account, running on my own domain (although you don't have to) containing all my previous emails, contacts and calendar events.
<h3>What's next?</h3>
Having a new email address and not telling anyone is a bit like a broken pencil - pointless. So I now need to notify my contacts that I have a new address (in the full knowledge that many won't bother up update their address books) and also update my subscribed services like Amazon and PayPal. I'll let you know how I get on with that in a future post.

Also, I am currently accessing this account from the Webmail interface but will investigate Desktop and Mobile clients in due course.
Author: Dave Carson
Title: Goodbye GMail - Step 1 anyway

Content:
<img class="wp-image-77 alignleft" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/02/society_clipart.png" alt="society_clipart" width="244" height="244" />

Society, i.e. <span style="text-decoration:underline;"><strong>us</strong></span>!

It shouldn't come as much of a shock really - the clue is in the title after all!

However, the news is currently filled with reports of how Social Media isn't doing enough to stop bullying and the posting of inappropriate content, such as self-harm, hate speech, mis-information and fake news but whose fault is that really?

There will always be a minority of the population who will try to exploit the rest for their own gain, whether that's financial or just self-gratification. It was like it before the Internet let alone Social Media and it will be like it until the Sun consumes this planet (unless we've seen ourselves off before then).
<h2>Facebook fanboy?</h2>
Now, I'm not a big fan of Facebook, or any of the social media platforms really, and extricated myself back in early 2018 - a truly liberating experience I can tell you. But I didn't leave because of anything that Facebook did or didn't do - I left because I wasn't really getting anything out of being there.

My feed was constantly filled with utter drivel and while there were a number of ads dotted around the majority of this crap was being posted by my friends and family - harsh but true.

Is that Facebook's fault? Could they have saved me from yet another cat meme or Top 10 list of names of the people who are going to die next month - and if they could, should they? Who are they to say what posted, and let's be clear here - legal, content I should or shouldn't be interested in.
<h2>It's a problem of scale</h2>
Consider the fact that in <a href="http://www.businessofapps.com/data/youtube-statistics/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">2018 YouTube users uploaded over 300 hours of content every minute</a>. Read that again - 300+ hours a minute! Add to this that over a billion hours are watched worldwide everyday and you may see the scale of the problem here - and the problem is scale!

Now, Facebook has more users than YouTube and in <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2015/11/04/facebook-video-views/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">2018 video engagement increased to 8 billion views a day</a>.

And that's just the video content - imagine how many images have been uploaded while you have been reading this! It's mind-boggling!

These platforms have to deal with a scale that most of us cannot even comprehend - but in amongst all those videos of someones cat riding a robotic vacuum cleaner is more disturbing and sinister content (legal and illegal).

But how do they find this stuff and filter it out before anyone sees it? How do they determine what is appropriate and what is not. Well, they can't - in real time and at that scale it just isn't possible, regardless of what the papers will tell you.
<h2>Surely this can be fixed with Artificial Intelligence</h2>
I don't think AI can save us here and to my mind it is only Real Stupidity that thinks it can at that scale.

Just how can a machine analyse a video in real-time and determine whether it contains hate speech or not?
<h2>So, what's my solution?</h2>
Well, I don't have one - maybe there isn't one and frankly, is there really a problem to be fixed here? This is what happens when you let society express itself. Maybe we are just ashamed of that and want to be seen to be doing something about it.

There are noises about Social Media platforms being banned in certain countries - <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/social-media-ban-uk-instagram-facebook-twitter-molly-russell-death-self-harm-samaritans-a8749121.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">including the UK</a> - but what will that achieve?

If all social media platforms were to be switched off tomorrow - who would lose out, really?

The majority of people on social media are decent and law abiding, merely keeping in touch with their friends, family and followers. Why do they have to be denied this because a few people can't behave themselves? Why is it always the good people who lose out while the dickheads of the world carry on regardless - moving on to the next thing which they will ultimately ruin for everyone and so the process starts again?!

Where does it stop?

Ban cars because too many people are speeding?

Ban phones because too many people use them while driving?

Most people can behave themselves in most areas of life, so why should we all be penalised because of the minority of society that can't?
Author: Dave Carson
Title: The problem with Social Media is...

Content:
<img class="  wp-image-83 alignleft" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/04/imposter.jpg" alt="imposter" width="133" height="167" /><a href="https://www.itv.com/news/westcountry/2019-03-20/generation-anxious-the-rise-of-imposter-syndrome-amongst-young-people/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Apparently a third of Generation Z, those aged between 9 and 21, say that they are anxious and have Imposter Syndrome</a> - which means they believe that they have somehow cheated their way into a job and they they are worried about being found out and sacked.

Now - before I offer my opinion I would ask you you read the above paragraph again.

I think that we can discount those aged from 9 to 16 here - a paper round isn't really a career move here - so that leaves us with 16 to 21 year olds and apparently, despite only having worked up to 5 years in any given job they are labelling themselves as Imposters.

What a load of old tosh!

Why the hell do these kids think that they need to know it all straight out of the gate - why the need for instant and total gratification all the damn time?

In the article linked above there is a young woman starting out as a software developer, a career path I'm already 20 years into, and she says "When I got my first and second jobs, I kind of thought that somehow, I had cheated my way into them". While that's not a particularly nice feeling, why on earth should they think that, as a graduate, she would need to know so much.

In these jobs she will probably have been surrounded by developers with more experience and maybe that set her thought process going. But I have news for you Ms Amini, those around you most certainly don't know it all. In fact, regardless of their age, they will probably be having thoughts about having Imposter Syndrome themselves.

If you find yourself feeling the same I urge you to watch this <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hER0Qp6QJNU" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Simon Sinek video</a> - specifically on <span style="text-decoration:underline;"><strong>Millennials in the Workplace</strong></span>.

You see, I'm not saying that Imposter Syndrome isn't a real thing - far from it.

There are well respected people in the Software Development arena, <a href="https://www.hanselman.com/blog/ImAPhonyAreYou.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Scott Hanselmen</a> and <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/31572054-the-imposter-s-handbook" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Rob Conery</a> to name but two, people I look up to, thay believe that they are <img class="  wp-image-84 alignright" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/04/31572054.jpg" alt="31572054" width="213" height="331" />imposters too.

The thing is this - you can either let it drag you down or drive you on.

Kids these days seem to be far too quick to decide that they can't do something and just give up.

Technology never stands still and if you are in a technology led career then you have a choice. You can keep doing the same thing, year after year or you can move with the times.

Doing the former is not a problem if you're happy with it - 10 years experience but the last 5 have all been the same year repeated over and over. People make a good living maintaining legacy systems.

Doing the latter is hard work - a constant task of weighing up what to learn and what to let pass you by. Evenings of reading blogs, watching online courses and devising 'pet projects' so that you can practice your new skills. But this will not make you an expert. Getting a job based on these limited skills doesn't make you an imposter - not in my opinion and Richard Branson agrees with me

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-82" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/04/richard-branson-quote-opportunity.jpg" alt="richard-branson-quote-opportunity" width="1200" height="630" />

If the likes of Richard Branson advocates this approach - then I'm going to give myself a pass on whether I have Imposter Syndrome or not.
Author: Dave Carson
Title: Generation Z and the Imposter Syndrome

Content:
Well things are really starting to get out of hand now - <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2019/4/18/18485089/facebook-email-password-contacts-upload-1-5-million-security-cybersecurity" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Facebook has admitted asking for personal email credentials and then downloading users contacts without permission</a>. But it's OK because it was 'unintentional'! Not withstanding the fact that they must have actually written the code to do this - who the hell thought it was an acceptable idea to request a users personal email credentials in the first place? Will they want my debit card PIN next - what about my damn DNA?

How much longer will the masses put up with this crap? Are they all still so absorbed with getting the 'Likes' that they are willing to give up everything - from privacy to self-respect? Unfortunately, it would appear so!

Well, I pulled the final Facebook plug and removed my business Page and the profile that it relied on to exist in the first place. I don't suppose that Facebook will notice I've gone completely now (or frankly that they would care) - but it make me feel a bit better.

I've also gone a little further, although nothing significant in the big scheme of things, and ditched Chrome in favour of Firefox with DuckDuckGo replacing Google as the default search engine.

What has Google done to upset me? Well, nothing new really - same as always, I'm no longer happy whoring myself for "free" services in return for information that frankly I don't want to give away anymore.

Google used to be a search engine - and that was that. Nothing really sinister there - a search engine doing things differently and making Internet Search significantly better.

But now Google is much more than that and has gotten far too big to control - a bit like Agent Smith in The Matrix. Uncontrollable, everywhere you look and everywhere you go.

I'm already <a href="https://davecarson.me/2019/02/18/goodbye-gmail-step-1-anyway/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">in the process of moving away from GMail</a> and while that may take a little while I'm happy with the progress I've made.

I've ditched the GMail app in favor of <a href="https://sparkmailapp.com/blog/spark-mail-arrives-on-android" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Spark</a> which seems to be working well for me and I'm also working out how to integrate the Calendar app on my phone with my new Fastmail account. There are a few apps that perform the synchronisation between the two but the jury is out regarding whether I can commit to any of them. It's a similar story for my Contacts - Google Contacts just works but it's a little harder if you're not a slave to the machine. Harder - but not impossible!

Today I also considered moving to a different Android distribution - one not provided by Google. I have run these before and had mixed results - the main problem being the access to the apps I need/want. Without access to the Google Play Store I would be pretty limited in my choice of applications - but there is choice!

I have a 'spare' Samsung Galaxy S7 and am considering configuring it to be a Google free zone. It won't be my daily device - not initially anyway - but a vehicle to deteremine whether it is actually possible. Maybe then I can also be free of <a href="https://www.howtogeek.com/195647/googles-location-history-is-still-recording-your-every-move/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Google tracking my location - even though I thought I'd turned that off</a>!

Watch this space :-)
Author: Dave Carson
Title: Falling a little further off the Grid

Content:
<img class="  wp-image-93 alignleft" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/06/61-fzzblpsl._sx569_.jpg" alt="61-FZzBlpsL._SX569_" width="267" height="267" />So, in a previous post I mentioned trying to get my old Samsung Galaxy S7 running different flavour of Android - one that doesn't rely on Google as much and one that doesn't come with bloatware, including Facebook (I'm looking at you Samsung).

Well, as it turned out this wasn't as easy as it used to be - I ran CyanogenMod on a HTC Hero some years ago and it was pretty straightforward to install etc. Maybe it's the way Android is going, but it's certainly not that easy now.

So what alternative did I have? Well, enter the <a href="https://www.oneplus.com/uk" target="_blank" rel="noopener">OnePlus</a> range of handsets - the <a href="https://www.oneplus.com/uk/6t" target="_blank" rel="noopener">6T model</a> in particular.

These handsets run a modified version of Android called <a href="https://www.oneplus.com/uk/oxygenos" target="_blank" rel="noopener">OxygenOS</a> which runs on some quite impressive hardware - certainly an upgrade from my Pixel 2XL.

I've bought a Sim free version this phone, on offer from Amazon for 'only' Â£470. For now I'm using my existing EE Sim but this may well change in August when my contract is due.

Anyway - the whole point of this was to reduce the level of data that I was sharing with Google, so what have I done there?

Previously I've always loved the fact that when I bought a new phone all I had to do was sign in and my contacts, calendar and photos would just appear - as if by magic.
<h2>Contacts and Appointments</h2>
But now that I've moved my personal and business email accounts to Fastmail all of my contacts and calendar events are stored there as well - but Android doesn't know anything about them so I've had to use my defunct Gmail account to store them.

After a bit of research I found a couple of apps, <a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.dmfs.carddav.Sync&amp;hl=en_GB" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CardDAV</a> and <a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.dmfs.caldav.lib&amp;hl=en_GB" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CalDAV</a>, which would act as a bridge between compatible email providers, such as Fastmail, and Android. There are free versions but I paid less than Â£1.00 each so they didn't break the bank.

So with my new handset out of the box I created a new, clean Google account - I maybe wrong but my understanding is that I still need one especially if I want to use the Google Play Store.

Once logged into the handset I promptly turned off all of the syncing and the like and installed my email apps (Fastmail for business and <a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.readdle.spark&amp;hl=en" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Spark</a> for personal) and the Card/CalDAV apps. A quick bit of configuration later (logging in and selecting the required address books to sync) and I soon had all my contacts and appointments on my device. Updates on the phone are sync'd to the Fastmail servers and vice-versa.
<h2>Photos</h2>
Photos is a different matter altogether - I mean, where can you store all your photos if not on Google?

Well, <a href="https://owncloud.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">OwnCloud</a> - that's where.

Think of OwnCloud as an alternative to Dropbox. I use to to backup files on my laptops and workstations as well as to transfer files between them all.

But surely that's just storing the data with another service..!? Well, not quite.

While I have hosted a previous instance of OwnCloud on a RaspberryPi in my home office I am now utilising a virtual private server (VPS) - actually a <a href="https://www.digitalocean.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Digital Ocean</a> "Droplet" - for my current instance.

After installing the OwnCloud app I am now not only able to access the sync'd data from my other systems, but also configure it to sync photos as I take them - storing a copy off my device in case the worst happens.

Ok, I won't get the '2 years ago today' notifications from Google anymore - but you know what? As interesting as it was to look back, I don't think I'll miss them.
<h2>Now What?</h2>
Well it's early days at the moment but I'm optimistic about what I've created here.

True, I still have a Google account in the mix and I may well want to utilise some location based services - Maps, "Near Me" &amp; Navigation for instance, so I'm not going to get in a spin about this.

Hopefully I will stop getting the 'Location Timeline' emails informing me of the 'Cities', 'Restaurants' and other points of interest that I've visited in the previous month - my 'clean' Google account may get a bit polluted but I never intend on checking that inbox anyway.
Author: Dave Carson
Title: New phone, goodbye Google?

Content:
<img class="  wp-image-105 alignleft" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/recycling-symbol-icon-outline-solid-light-green.png" alt="recycling-symbol-icon-outline-solid-light-green" width="215" height="210" />Before you race down to the comments to berate me about being an eco-terrorist let me make my case.

Firstly, I do recycle. I separate waste into the appropriate bins and dutifully drag them out to the pavement each week. I wash the food trays, rinse the milk cartons and remove the tops from plastic bottles.

But why am I bothering?

Let's be honest here, any change that my contribution will make will come after I'm dead and gone - and it doesn't look like the youth that will be come behind me really give a shit!

I live on the South Coast of the UK and have a lovely beach on my doorstep. Driving along the seafront I frequently see discarded fast-food containers which (I have witnessed) have been left behind by young drivers who can't be arsed to get out of their cars and walk the 20 feet to a bin and dispose of them properly.

Try to take them to task about this and you normally get a barrage of abuse - so I don't really bother anymore.

But it's not just these disrespectful guys (and girls!) that don't appear to care though - my own step-children really don't seem to get it.

All too often I will go out to my general waste bin and find that one of the kids has essentially emptied the contents of their car into it the last time they visited. Yes, they have their own bins but they don't park near them so when they pull on the drive they take their chance.

I don't really care about the fact that this hasn't been bagged up but all too often there are bottles, cardboard and other recyclable waste in there. They could have put these items in our recycling containers but that would require walking through the house with their rubbish - so they don't bother.

Don't get me started on leaving the lights on - even in their own homes where you would think they would think twice as they pay the bills.

So why should I bother - if even normally sensible kids like this won't and other local youngsters don't care?
Author: Dave Carson
Title: Recycle - why bother?

Author: Dave Carson
Title: The British Compensation Scurge

Content:
<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-120" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/11/lmgtfy.png" alt="lmgtfy" width="2474" height="851" />Why do people feel the need to interupt you to ask a question that they could easily look up themselves on Google (or your search engine of choice - I use Duck Duck Go!)?

This is especially irritating when the person asking the question is normally staring at their smartphone and could just answer their own question there and then.
<blockquote>"What time does &lt;some shop&gt; close?"

"What time does the 57 bus stop down the road?"</blockquote>
I mean - how the bloody hell should I know? Look it up.!!!

I don'y mind helping people who are prepared to help themselves and put some effort in before just asking for help. It's not like they don't know how to use the internet after all.

Some time ago my stepson was supposed to be chasing up a potential job opportunity - but never seemed to get around to it.

When asked, "Why have you not called them?" he responded, "I don't have their phone number".

Really? Really? Look it the f*ck up!

As a teenager he had no problem finding all manner of pornography and upgrades for his MS Flight Simulator installation, but look up a phone number? Can you do that on the Internet?

It's more ittitating when I get a text message asking me something that could so easily have been looked on on the device that was clearly in their bloody hands!

Well, no more!

While it will take some effort on my part I'll be using the '<a href="https://lmgtfy.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Let Me Google That For You</a>' site to show them just how easy it is!

I remember when this was a new site but completely forget about it. It has certainly come a long way.

Go to the site and select from one of the supported search engines.

Next, enter your search term and see what you get back - chances are that you won't need to search too hard for what is being asked for.

<img class="  wp-image-121 alignleft" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2019/11/lmgtfy-app.png" alt="lmgtfy-app" width="252" height="468" />

When you're happy with the results click 'Get Link' and the link will be copied to your clipboard.

Paste that into a text message and send it.

When they click the link (and regardless of how many time you've told them not to click on random links, they probably will anyway) their browser will show them a Google-like page (assuming you picked Google) and some animated instructions will show them what they need to do:

It may take a few attempts but hopefully they will soon get the message.

There's even <a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.wilderpereira.lmgtfygen&amp;hl=en" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a mobile app available on the Play Store</a> which currently has a rating of 4.7 so may well be worth a look.
Author: Dave Carson
Title: Let me Google that for you - seeing you can't be bothered!

Content:
<a href="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2020/04/misogyny-definition.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img class="alignleft wp-image-140 size-medium" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2020/04/misogyny-definition.png?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="152" /></a>So, I while on lockdown in the UK I, like many others, am spending more some on Twitter. Sure, like most social networks, it's a bit of a haven for fake news, misinformation and of course the haters and trolls, it's not as toxic as Facebook.

<img class="size-full wp-image-135 alignright" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2020/04/coronavirus-test.png" alt="" width="300" height="221" />

When I saw a post being retweeted with the following image showing how deep the swab is taken when testing for the coronavirus expressing how unpleasant it looked I decided to respond in kind; I retweeted it with my own thoughts - and that's were the trouble started.

The woman who retweeted took exception to me retweeting it, essentially claiming that I was 'policing comments made by women' on Twitter. Apparently this is a 'Twitter technique used by misogynists'.

I was dumbfounded - who the hell was this person (who happened to be a woman) to label me like that because of an innocuous retweet. I could rant on about this but that will probably end up with me being labelled as something else I'm not but this in itself highlights a problem.

<a href="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2020/04/misogynist-tweet.png" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img class="alignleft wp-image-142 size-medium" src="https://davecarsonme.files.wordpress.com/2020/04/misogynist-tweet.png?w=196" alt="" width="196" height="300" /></a>Why it is OK for this person (I'm doing it again) to put a label on me without knowing a thing about me, apart from my opinion on whether I would prefer to take the test regardless of the discomfort, but I feel like I cannot respond without treading on eggshells in case I bring the world of Twitter to my door.

Looking at my antagonists other tweets she doesn't seem to be so held back on passing comments on her retweets, be the original tweeter male or female - she quite opinionated in fact. So why the need to try to suppress my comments using the 'anti-woman' angle as a defense against any comeback?

Why are people (men and women) so easy to offend these days? It's not like I made any reference to anyone except myself in my response - so with the need to attack me for having a differing opinion? Are men not allowed to have one anymore, especially when it's deemed to be at the expense of a womans?

There are a lot of tweets saying that when we come through this, which we will, then we will all be more appreciative and more tolerant of those around us. At the moment, that doesn't seem to be a universal belief.
Author: Dave Carson
Title: So, men can't have an opinion anymore?
